metadata.case_name: V. S. Menon v. Union of India & Anr.

facts.text: Appellant appointed in June 1943 as an Engineering Supervisor by the second respondent.
Appellant suspended from service in January 1949 on account of certain activities considered objectionable.
Appellant served with notice to show cause; case considered by Committee of Advisers who recommended retention in service.
Appellant reinstated with effect from May 26, 1951.
Appellant passed departmental examination in 1952 and appointed as officiating Sub-Divisional Officer, Telegraphs at Nagpur.

Show-cause notice dated November 3, 1952 under rr. 3 and 4 of Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949, alleging continued association with others engaged in subversive activities after reinstatement.
Appellant submitted 9-page reply on November 17, 1952 denying charges and requesting personal hearing before Director General and Committee of Advisers.
Appellant requested on January 23, 1953 that evidence be made available at oral hearing.
Appellant granted personal hearing by second respondent (Director General) on January 28, 1953.
Second show-cause notice dated May 19, 1953 stating Committee of Advisers provisionally of opinion that sufficient grounds exist for compulsory retirement.
Order of compulsory retirement dated August 28, 1953 under r.3 with prior approval of President.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in High Court of Judicature at Nagpur; dismissed by Full Bench.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court Circuit Bench Delhi; dismissed by single Judge Falshaw, J. on September 10, 1957.
Letters Patent Appeal dismissed by Division Bench (Khosla, J. and Shamsher Bahadur, J.) on October 6, 1960.
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on February 21, 1961.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Rules are a colourable exercise of power under s.241(2) of Government of India Act, 1935.
Whether the Rules violate s.241(3) of Government of India Act, 1935.
Whether the Rules provide for or authorise constitution of Committee of Advisers.
Whether the charge against petitioner is outside r.3, requiring participation in subversive activities rather than mere association.
Whether reasonable opportunity was given, as charges were vague and evidence withheld.
Whether opportunity of hearing by Committee of Advisers was denied despite request.
Whether compulsory retirement is premature termination amounting to penalty requiring proper enquiry.
Whether the charge framed against appellant falls within r.3 of the Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rules are colourable exercise of power under s.241(2) of Govt of India Act, 1935, as purpose is not regulation of conditions of service.
Rules violate s.241(3) of Govt of India Act, 1935.
Rules do not provide for or authorise constitution of Committee of Advisers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949

petitioner_arguments.text: Charge outside r.3, which requires participation in subversive activities, not mere association.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r.3, Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949

petitioner_arguments.text: No reasonable opportunity as charges vague without particulars and evidence withheld on ground of secret documents.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r.4, Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949

petitioner_arguments.text: No opportunity of hearing by Committee of Advisers despite special request.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949

petitioner_arguments.text: Compulsory retirement is premature termination, a penalty requiring appropriate enquiry.

respondent_arguments.text: Charge should not be too strictly construed; compulsory retirement under Rules does not amount to dismissal or removal under Art. 311.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949; Art. 311, Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Enquiry was proper and reasonable opportunity afforded.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: r.4, Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949

court_reasoning.text: Charge alleges only continued association with others engaged in subversive activities, not that appellant was engaged or reasonably suspected to be engaged in subversive activities himself or in association with others, which is required under r.3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule of penal character must be strictly construed; mere association insufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Allegations of contact with communists and interest in political activities do not amount to subversive activities unless calculated to subvert government; Communist party not banned.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No allegation of active participation in subversive activities.

court_reasoning.text: Balakotaiah case distinguished as there charges showed engagement in subversive activities, not mere communism; no corresponding rule to r.148 Railway Code, so termination is penal removal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Termination tantamount to removal by penalty, attracting Art. 226 relief.

holdings.text: Charge does not fall within r.3 as it only alleges association, not engagement or suspicion thereof in subversive activities.
Premature termination not justified under r.3, tantamount to penal removal.
Appellant entitled to declaration that service not legally terminated.

precedents_cited.relevance: Validates r.3 but on facts where charges alleged engagement in subversive activities, not mere association; termination not under Art. 311.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs compulsory retirement for subversive activities; charge must strictly comply; procedure under r.4 not followed due to defective charge.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction available; termination not simple discharge but penal, attracting protections.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Source of rule-making power challenged as colourable.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; declaration that appellant's service was not legally terminated in accordance with r.3 of the Rules, as charge defective.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that service not legally terminated.

key_quotes.text: "A Government servant who, in the opinion of the Competent authority is engaged in or is reasonably suspected to be engaged in subversive activities or is associated with others in subversive activities in such a manner as to raise doubts about his reliability may be compulsorily retired from service."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes r.3 to show strict requirements not met by charge.

key_quotes.text: "As the rule is of a penal character, it has to be very strictly construed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for invalidating charge due to non-compliance.

key_quotes.text: "Subversive activity, in order to bring the person within the purview of the rule must amount to actively pursuing such activities as are calculated to subvert the government established by law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies threshold for subversive activities beyond mere association.
